text: <@U09FPVB6KD4> this could be of your interest <https://learn.nikau.io/courses/course-v1:Nikau+TF2+2025_T4/about>

attachments.text: Tunnel and Fortress is a live, coached and intensive training series empowering participants to deploy and secure sovereign server infrastructure.
attachments.title: Tunnel and Fortress

elements.text: this could be of your interest

text:
Hi <@U02PUDETGRW> That's a cool initiative. I actually had seen an interview with Julian Oliver on one of our public media outlets, not so long ago. I have been personally exploring the local first and peer to peer software paradigms, because of many of the issues that Julian identifies, but with the traditional client/server paradigm there still remains the issue of system persistence, if the admin team breaks down, then the system goes down too. That's a major problem in the gaming scene at the moment. Local first software and peer to peer frameworks like libp2p mitigates that risk significantly. Naturally there are still lots of useful tools that are developed under the traditional client/server architecture paradigm, so it will take some time to develop local-first p2p tools to replace them.

I'm actually working on a workforce skills development provider for indigenous youth in my community to provide them with highly demanded skills that prepares them for a rapidly changing economy, that offers them cultural sovereignty and economic security not available elsewhere.

I'm currently talking with a math education researcher who developed a culturally relevant mathematics education pedagogy and have corresponded with Ron Eglash about developing something similar that teaches computing principles.
<https://tinyurl.com/4kxr36v9>
<https://csdt.org/>

The Bobbie Maths teaching method is physically embodied and conducted in groups so I thought that perhaps some of the tech that Bret Victor developed for Dynamicland would be really valuable for supporting it.

I have been personally exploring the local first and peer to peer software paradigms, because of many of the issues that Julian identifies, but with the traditional client/server paradigm there still remains the issue of system persistence, if the admin team breaks down, then the system goes down too. That's a major problem in the gaming scene at the moment. Local first software and peer to peer frameworks like libp2p mitigates that risk significantly. Naturally there are still lots of useful tools that are developed under the traditional client/server architecture paradigm, so it will take some time to develop local-first p2p tools to replace them.

I'm actually working on a workforce skills development provider for indigenous youth in my community to provide them with highly demanded skills that prepares them for a rapidly changing economy, that offers them cultural sovereignty and economic security not available elsewhere.

I'm currently talking with a math education researcher who developed a culturally relevant mathematics education pedagogy and have corresponded with Ron Eglash about developing something similar that teaches computing principles.

The Bobbie Maths teaching method is physically embodied and conducted in groups so I thought that perhaps some of the tech that Bret Victor developed for Dynamicland would be really valuable for supporting it.
